item.title: Covid-19: Care home residents in England allowed two visitors from 12 April
item.description: From 12 April, two people - as well as babies and young children - will be allowed for indoor visits.

item.title: Rowley Regis dog attack: Woman, 85, killed after 'dogs get through fence hole'
item.description: The death of the 85-year-old woman is "tragic and horrific", say police.

item.title: Richard Okorogheye: Police appeal to missing student to 'get in touch'
item.description: A search of Epping Forest, near where Richard Okorogheye was last seen, enters a third day.

item.title: Covid: Clean-up after crowds party in Cardiff Bay despite restrictions
item.description: People "intent" on breaking Covid-19 rules left a "significant" amount of rubbish, says council.

item.title: US Capitol: Police officer dies after car rams security barrier
item.description: The driver of the vehicle was shot dead by police after lunging at officers with a knife.

item.title: Covid-19: Italy returns to strict lockdown for Easter
item.description: The measures come as Italy battles a third wave of the pandemic, with more than 20,000 new cases daily.

item.title: Covid-19: Seven UK blood clot deaths after AstraZeneca vaccine
item.description: The regulator confirms the deaths to the BBC, but says the benefits continue to outweigh any risk.

item.title: Free climber George King scales skyscraper hotel in Barcelona without permission.
item.description: George King, 21, was met by police after climbing a skyscraper hotel without safety equipment.

item.title: Police uncover teenage girl ‘suicide’ Instagram group
item.description: Twelve UK girls, aged between 12 and 16, were part of a chat group that led to "serious self-harm".

item.title: Egypt mummies to pass through Cairo in ancient rulers' parade
item.description: The Cairo spectacle will see the remains of 18 kings and four queens taken to a new resting place.

item.title: The Papers: Staycation 'stampede' and NHS future blueprint
item.description: Covid's impact on holidays and the health service are two dominant stories on Saturday's front pages.

item.title: Belgian police 'are supposed to protect us'
item.description: Campaigners in Belgium call for urgent reform of the police after a series of high profile deaths in custody.

item.title: World’s largest ocean monitoring system BRUVS launched
item.description: Marine scientist Professor Jessica Meeuwig on her hopes for a new ocean monitoring system.

item.title: Ros Atkins On… Macron’s Covid-19 Crisis
item.description: Coronavirus has forced France into a third lockdown and raised questions about President Emmanuel Macron’s leadership.

item.title: Abigail Thorn: 'I came out as trans and made headlines'
item.description: Abigail Thorn is behind the popular channel Philosophy Tube, which has over 900,000 subscribers.

item.title: Lockdown policing: Cracking down on the coronavirus rule breakers
item.description: The BBC joined Lancashire Police as they broke up gatherings breaching lockdown rules.

item.title: Week in pictures: 27 March - 2 April 2021
item.description: A selection of powerful images taken around the world this week.

item.title: Dinosaur-killing asteroid strike gave rise to Amazon rainforest
item.description: The asteroid that killed off the dinosaurs gave birth to tropical rainforests, a study suggests.

item.title: USS Johnston: Sub dives to deepest-known shipwreck
item.description: A submersible has reached the USS Johnston, which lies 6.5km beneath the waves in the Pacific.

item.title: Video captures deer flying through a school bus windshield
item.description: A student was taking a morning nap when he was abruptly woken up by something unexpected.

item.title: Easter Weekend: How to keep socially anxious seals safe
item.description: If you're visiting the coast this Easter Weekend, conservationists want you to keep your distance from seals.

item.title: Race report: Was controversy part of the plan?
item.description: How the government handled the release of a contentious report on racial disparity in the UK.

item.title: Violence against women: Loss, death and grieving in public
item.description: A month since Sarah Everard disappeared, two women share what it's like to grieve in the public eye.

item.title: Street racing: They're fast, Atlanta's furious
item.description: Screeching tyres disturb the peace in Atlanta, Georgia, as street racers claim the city's highways.

item.title: The women fighting South Africa's 'infodemic'
item.description: South Africa has faced a wave of Covid misinformation, but volunteers are fighting back.

item.title: My Money: 'Lockdown has been a blessing in disguise'
item.description: Thanucha, a pharmacology student from Hertfordshire, talks us through her lockdown spending.

item.title: Writing songs in lockdown: 'It was an escape'
item.description: Musicians amateur and professional have joined in a BBC-led project to document lockdown songs.

item.title: How Instagram’s influencers changed the model industry
item.description: Models have increasingly been asked to shoot their own photographs during the pandemic.

item.title: Evidence suggests Ethiopian military carried out massacre in Tigray
item.description: A BBC Africa Eye investigation uncovers the location of a massacre, and evidence linking it to the military.

item.title: Liverpool boss Jurgen Klopp shocked by Trent Alexander-Arnold England omission
item.description: Liverpool boss Jurgen Klopp says he could not understand the move to leave Trent Alexander-Arnold out of the England squad.

item.title: ‘The comeback to end all comebacks’ - Cleall set for England Six Nations return
item.description: The Women's Six Nations finally returns on Saturday two months later than planned, but for England prop Bryony Cleall the wait has been significantly longer.

item.title: Police called to Stadium of Light as Robinson claims Oxford keeper headbutted
item.description: Police are called after claims Oxford United goalkeeper Jack Stevens was headbutted during their League One defeat at Sunderland.

item.title: F1 and football should have more purpose – Rosberg
item.description: Former Formula 1 world champion Nico Rosberg says sport must embrace purpose, and that F1 needs to do more.

item.title: What's the roadmap for lifting lockdown?
item.description: The rules on how many people can meet outdoors are changing, as lockdown is eased.

item.title: Covid: When can pubs and restaurants reopen?
item.description: Hospitality venues are set to gradually open up in the spring as lockdown eases across the UK.

item.title: What are the rules for weddings and when can I hold a reception?
item.description: Wedding ceremonies are still restricted across the UK, but the rules are easing.

item.title: Covid: What’s the problem with the EU vaccine rollout?
item.description: The coronavirus vaccine is being rolled out across the EU but there have been delays.

item.title: Lockdown rules: What are the restrictions in your area?
item.description: Use our search tool to find out about coronavirus rules and restrictions where you live.

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the rules for places of worship?
item.description: Places of worship are open across much of the UK, despite lockdown.

item.title: Covid: What is the rule of six and what are the social distancing rules?
item.description: Lockdown rules are being eased further in England and Wales so more people can meet up outside.

item.title: Coronavirus: When will pools, gyms, pubs and hairdressers open?
item.description: Lockdown has been eased further - but what does it mean for hairdressers, pubs and gyms?

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in your area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: Covid: How are European countries tackling the pandemic?
item.description: Are European countries relaxing restrictions put in place to control a new wave of infections?

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the rules for face masks or face coverings?
item.description: As the UK cautiously unlocks, experts will review the evidence on when and where masks are needed.

item.title: Covid: What's happened to crime during the pandemic?
item.description: From dog theft to drug crime, lockdown has led to some big changes in policing.

item.title: What are the rules on dating now? And other questions
item.description: We answer some of your questions about England's roadmap out of lockdown, and other Covid-related issues.

item.title: Covid: When will I get the vaccine?
item.description: People aged 50 and over are urged to book their Covid vaccine in the next few days.

item.title: Covid: When can I go on holiday abroad or in the UK?
item.description: Anyone in England who travels abroad without good reason will soon face a £5000 fine.

item.title: Unemployment rate: How many people are out of work?
item.description: The unemployment rate is rising as Covid hits different parts of the economy.

item.title: Covid: The inside story of the government's battle against the virus
item.description: Twenty of Downing Street's most senior politicians, officials and former officials take you "into the room" where essential Covid decisions were being made.

item.title: Covid: The countries that nailed it, and what we can learn from them
item.description: A year into the pandemic, we look at countries that have had some success in tackling the virus.

item.title: Coronavirus: Your tributes to those who have died
item.description: A collection of your tributes to some of the thousands of people in the UK who have died with coronavirus.

item.title: Covid: What is the Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine?
item.description: The Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccines should save many lives, say experts.

item.title: The cost of speaking up against China
item.description: Uyghurs abroad describe a pattern of harassment and intimidation they say is designed to silence them.

item.title: Letterbox contact: ‘Don’t my birth children have a right to know I’m dying?'
item.description: Diagnosed with a terminal illness, Hanna wanted to tell the twins taken from her at 16 - but had no way of reaching them.

item.title: Naga Munchetty: It’s time to talk about race
item.description: Naga Munchetty travelled across the UK to understand what race and racism means today.

item.title: The vaccine misinformation battle raging in France
item.description: Online conspiracy theories are exacerbating existing vaccine scepticism.
